The "Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Act of 2000" defines terms for the establishment of a program by the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 3. ESTABLISHMENT OF THE PROGRAM. The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program is established within the Department of the Interior with goals to decrease fish mortality and prevent fish from entering water supply systems. The Secretary will develop projects to mitigate impacts on fisheries. The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program aims to reduce fish mortality and prevent fish from entering water supply systems. The Secretary will develop projects to mitigate impacts on fisheries in the Pacific Ocean drainage area. The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program aims to reduce fish mortality and prevent fish from entering water supply systems in the Pacific Ocean drainage area. Projects eligible under the Program include the development, improvement, or installation of fish screens, fish passage devices, and other related features agreed upon by relevant stakeholders. Additionally, States will conduct inventories to determine the need and priority for these projects. The Secretary will prioritize projects costing less than $5,000,000, including fish screens, fish passage devices, and related features agreed upon by stakeholders. States will conduct inventories to assess project needs and priorities. Non-Federal participation in the Program is voluntary, and the Secretary will not hold non-Federal entities financially responsible unless they apply. Projects on U.S. owned land will not require reimbursement. Evaluation and prioritization of projects will be based on cost and stakeholder agreements. Evaluation and prioritization of projects for development under the Program will be based on benefits to native fish species, size and type of water diversion, availability of funding sources, cost effectiveness, and additional opportunities for biological or water delivery system benefits. Eligibility requirements will also be considered. Eligibility requirements for projects under the Program include meeting Secretary and State requirements, agreement from all relevant entities, consultation with various agencies, and utilization of available data. The non-Federal share of the cost for projects under the Program on non-Federal land is 35 percent. Non-Federal participants must provide necessary land and resources for the project, which will be credited towards the project's value. The United States will provide land, easements, rights-of-way, and other necessary resources for the project. The value of these contributions will be credited towards the non-Federal share of project costs. Non-Federal participants are responsible for all costs associated with operating and maintaining projects on non-Federal land or facilities. The non-Federal participants are responsible for all costs associated with operating, maintaining, repairing, rehabilitating, and replacing the project on land or at a facility not owned by the United States. The Federal Government is responsible for these costs for projects carried out on Federal land or at a Federal facility. SEC. 8. LIMITATION ON ELIGIBILITY FOR FUNDING. A project funded under this Act cannot receive Federal funds from any other source for the same purpose. SEC. 9. REPORT. A project funded under this Act cannot receive Federal funds from any other source for the same purpose. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress after the third fiscal year, detailing completed projects, those to be completed in the future, and recommended Program changes based on project outcomes. Authorization of appropriations for projects funded under this Act is specified in Section 10. Authorized appropriations of $25,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2001-2005 under this Act. Limitations include not more than 25% of funds for projects in a single state, with a waiver option, and a cap of 6% for administrative expenses. The Secretary may waive the limitation on funds for projects in a single state if necessary. Additionally, no more than 6% of funds can be used for federal administrative expenses.
